[[Mentioned in Despatches]] |relations= |laterwork= Australian Secretary to [[Elizabeth II]] (1970) }} [[Lieutenant general (Australia)|Lieutenant General]] '''Sir Reginald George Pollard''', {{postnominals|country=AUS|size=100%|sep=,|KCVO|KBE|CB|DSO}} (20 January 1903 – 9 March 1978) was a senior commander in the [[Australian Army]], serving as [[Chief of Army (Australia)|Chief of the General Staff]] from 1960 to 1963. Born in [[Bathurst, New South Wales|Bathurst]], New South Wales, Pollard graduated from the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]], in 1924. A regular officer, he served as [[adjutant]]/[[quartermaster]] in several [[battalion]]s of the [[Australian Army Reserve|Citizens Military Forces]] (CMF) during the 1920s and 1930s. In 1938 he was posted to England to undertake staff training, which was cut short by the outbreak of the Second World War. Pollard joined the [[Second Australian Imperial Force]] in 1940, and the following year saw action with the [[7th Division (Australia)|7th Division]] in the Middle East, where he was [[mentioned in despatches]]. Promoted to [[colonel]] in 1942, he became senior staff officer of the 7th Division in [[New Guinea]], and was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] for his actions. He spent much of the remainder of the war in staff and training positions in Australia. Pollard's early post-war roles involved recruit training, land/air warfare, administration, and planning. In 1953, he was promoted to [[brigadier]] and took command of the Australian Army Component of the [[British Commonwealth Forces Korea]]. He joined the Military Board as a [[major general]] in 1954, and was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] the following year. In 1957 he was promoted to [[lieutenant general]] and took charge of [[2nd Military District (Australia)|Eastern Command]] in [[Sydney]]; two years later he was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]]. [[Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire|Knighted]] in 1961, as Chief of the General Staff he presided over the Army's reorganisation as a [[Pentropic organisation|pentropic]] structure, and worked towards making Duntroon a degree-granting institution. In 1962, he oversaw deployment of the first [[Australian Army Training Team Vietnam|team of Australian military advisors]] to [[South Vietnam]]. After retiring from the military in 1963, Pollard became [[Honorary Colonel]] of the [[Royal Australian Regiment]]; he served as Australian Secretary to [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] during the Royal Visit in 1970 and was appointed a [[Knight Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] the same year. He died at [[Wyrallah, New South Wales|Wyrallah]], New South Wales, in 1978. ==Early life== Reginald George Pollard was born on 20 January 1903 in [[Bathurst, New South Wales|Bathurst]], New South Wales, the third son of Albert Edgar Pollard, an English accountant, and his Australian wife Thalia Rebecca, née McLean.{{cite web|last=Clark|first=Chris|url=http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A160020b.htm|title=Pollard, Sir Reginald George (1903–1978)|work=[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]|accessdate=2 May 2015}} Schooled in Bathurst, Reg entered the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]], in 1921, and graduated with the [[Sword of Honour (Duntroon)|Sword of Honour]] for "exemplary conduct and performance" in 1924.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article31658745 |title=Royal Military College, Duntroon |newspaper=[[The Queanbeyan Age]] |date=12 December 1924 |accessdate=8 May 2015 |page=6 }} Pollard and fellow graduate [[Frederick Scherger]], winner of the [[King's Medal (Duntroon)|King's Medal]] and future [[air chief marshal]], applied to transfer to the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) under a scheme designed to augment the RAAF's officer corps, but only Scherger was accepted.Moore, ''Duntroon'', p. 64 The previous year, Pollard and Scherger had inaugurated a Duntroon tradition when they found a horse's jawbone during a field exercise. Inspired by the Biblical tale in which [[Samson]] slays the [[Philistines]] with the jawbone of an ass, they declared their find a lucky charm and brought it back to the college as a mascot; it became known as "Enobesra" (reportedly because "jawbone seemed so commonplace, an [[buttocks|arsebone]] sounded much more interesting and spelt backwards sounded both mysterious and respectable").Moore, ''Duntroon'', pp. 69–70 Ranked [[lieutenant]] in the Permanent Military Force (PMF), Pollard was appointed [[adjutant]]/[[quartermaster]] of the [[17th Battalion (Australia)|17th Battalion]] [[Australian Army Reserve|(Citizens Military Forces)]], headquartered at [[North Sydney, New South Wales|North Sydney]], in July 1925.''The Army List'', p. 185{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article142318440 |title=Biography: Lieut-Gen. Sir Reginald Pollard|newspaper=[[Western Herald (Bourke)|The Western Herald]]|date=1 February 1963 |accessdate=10 May 2015 |page=7 }} He married Daisy Ethel Potter, a typist, at St Andrew's Anglican Church, [[Strathfield]], on 31 October; ''[[The Bathurst Free Press and Mining Journal|The Bathurst Times]]'' reported that Daisy cut the cake with her husband's Sword of Honour.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article118051423 |title=Weddings |newspaper=[[The Bathurst Free Press and Mining Journal|The Bathurst Times]] |date=7 November 1925 |accessdate=8 May 2015 |page=7 }} Pollard departed for India on attachment to the [[British Army]] in September 1927, serving with the [[Royal Fusiliers]] and the [[York and Lancaster Regiment]]. He returned to Sydney in November the following year and was posted as adjutant/quartermaster to, successively, the [[18th Battalion (Australia)|18th Battalion]] (CMF) and, in September 1932, the [[44th Battalion (Australia)|44th Battalion]] (CMF). In December 1932, while serving with the 44th in [[Western Australia]], he was promoted to [[Captain (armed forces)|captain]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article159836536 |title=Personal |newspaper=[[The National Advocate]] |date=17 December 1932 |accessdate=8 May 2015 |page=5 }} Pollard was camp commandant of the National Rifle Association of Western Australia from 1934 to 1936.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article40964879 |title=Annual meeting|newspaper=[[The West Australian]] |date=3 October 1936 |accessdate=8 May 2015 |page=18 }} He was transferred to Army Headquarters, [[Melbourne]], in October 1936. His next posting, in July 1938, was as General Staff Officer Grade 3, Training and General Duties, at the 2nd District Base, [[Sydney]].Dawnay; Headlam, ''The Army Quarterly'', p. 161 In November 1938, Pollard travelled to England to attend [[Staff College, Camberley]]; he graduated in September 1939, the planned two-year course having been curtailed owing to the outbreak of the Second World War. ==Second World War== [[File:COL Reg Pollard 1945 (AWM 120538).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Colonel Pollard as Deputy Director of Military Operations, Melbourne, in December 1945|alt=Head-and-shoulders portrait of moustachioed man in military uniform at desk]] Following the declaration of war, Pollard served as Assistant Military Liaison Officer at the [[High Commission of Australia, London|Australian High Commission]], London; during this posting he spent two weeks attached to the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War II)|British Expeditionary Force]] in France. Promoted [[major]], he joined the [[Second Australian Imperial Force]] (AIF) in June 1940. The provisions of the ''Defence Act (1903)'' prohibited members of the PMF (or the CMF) fighting outside Australian territory except as volunteers in the AIF.Johnston, ''The Australian Army in World War II'', p. 5 Pollard was appointed [[brigade major]] of the [[25th Brigade (Australia)|25th Brigade]], an Australian infantry formation raised in England mostly from logistics personnel to help combat a possible invasion by [[Nazi Germany]].{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_13074.asp|title=25th Brigade|publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate=10 May 2015}} The brigade became part of the Australian [[9th Division (Australia)|9th Division]], and in January 1941 sailed for the [[Mediterranean and Middle East theatre of World War II|Middle East]]; it was transferred to the [[7th Division (Australia)|7th Division]] on arrival. In March, Pollard was assigned to the 7th Division's headquarters staff in Libya under Lieutenant General [[John Lavarack]].Long, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070234--1-.pdf ''To Benghazi'', p. 303] On 24 April, towards the end of the [[Western Desert Campaign|campaign in Cyrenaica]], Pollard led a raiding party on [[Jaghbub, Libya|Giarabub]], Libya, to remove [[Senussi]] civilians and destroy wells and ammunition. He took command of the [[2/31st Battalion (Australia)|2/31st Battalion]] at the end of June 1941, during the [[Syria–Lebanon Campaign|Syrian campaign]], after the battalion's commanding officer, Lieutenant Colonel [[Selwyn Porter]], was wounded.Dexter, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070043--1-.pdf ''Greece, Crete and Syria'', p. 464] A cease-fire on 12 July ended the campaign in Syria, and Pollard was [[mentioned in despatches]] for his service; the award was [[The London Gazette|gazetted]] on 30 December 1941.Dexter, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070045--1-.pdf ''Greece, Crete and Syria'', p. 513]{{LondonGazette |issue=35396 |date=30 December 1941 |startpage=7339 |endpage=7358 |accessdate=10 May 2015}} Pollard was promoted to [[lieutenant colonel]] in August 1941, and was responsible for establishing the AIF Junior Staff School in [[Mandatory Palestine|Palestine]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article45748508 |title=AIF men on staff |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]]|date=23 January 1942 |accessdate=10 May 2015 |page=9 }} He was raised to temporary [[colonel]] in March 1942 and posted to the AIF Staff in [[Ceylon]], where the [[16th Brigade (Australia)|16th]] and [[17th Brigade (Australia)|17th Brigades]] had been garrisoned while on their way back to Australia from the Middle East.McCarthy, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070133--1-.pdf ''South-West Pacific Area'', pp. 118–119] Returning to Australia in August, Pollard was appointed General Staff Officer Grade 1 of the [[6th Division (Australia)|6th Division]]; he served on its headquarters in [[Territory of Papua|Papua]] from September until mid-November 1942, when he became Major General [[George Alan Vasey|George Vasey]]'s senior staff officer at the 7th Division.McCarthy, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070142--1-.pdf ''South-West Pacific Area'', p. 414] Pollard received the [[Distinguished Service Order]] for his actions in operations at [[Battle of Buna–Gona|Gona and Sanananda]], during which he "displayed unlimited energy and ascertained vital information for use in future operations"; the award was promulgated on 21 December 1943.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17883560 |title=South-West Pacific |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=24 December 1943 |accessdate=12 May 2015 |page=7 }}{{LondonGazette |issue=36297 |date=21 December 1943 |startpage=5574 |supp=yes |accessdate=10 May 2015}} At the conclusion of the Papuan campaign in January 1943, Pollard was posted to [[Queensland]] with the 6th Division, which was undergoing training and reinforcement.Dexter, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070176--1-.pdf ''The New Guinea Offensives'', p. 55] He was Chief Instructor of the Senior Staff School at Duntroon from December 1943 until February 1945, when he became Deputy Director of Military Operations at General [[Thomas Blamey|Sir Thomas Blamey's]] Allied Land Forces Headquarters, based in Melbourne.Long, [https://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070305--1-.pdf ''The Final Campaigns'', p. 593] ==Post-war career== ===Rise to Chief of the General Staff=== [[File:Reg Pollard 1953 (AWM 148549).JPG|thumb|right|Brigadier Pollard as Commander of the Australian Army Component, British Commonwealth Forces Korea, July 1953|alt=Outdoor half-portrait of moustachioed man in summer military uniform with peaked cap]] Pollard held command of the Army's [[Greta Army Camp|Recruit Training Centre]] at [[Greta, New South Wales|Greta]], New South Wales, from February to May 1946. He spent the next two months attached to the headquarters staff of [[1st Military District (Australia)|Northern Command]]. In August he was posted to England to undertake a course at the [[Royal Air Force]]'s [[School of Land/Air Warfare|School of Air Support]] in [[Old Sarum]], and following his return in February 1947 was allotted to instruct at the soon-to-be-opened RAAF School of Air Support at [[Laverton, Victoria|Laverton]], Victoria.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article22409845 |title=Personal |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]]| date=19 February 1947 |accessdate=12 May 2015 |page=4 }} It was redesignated the School of Land/Air Warfare in March 1948 and relocated to [[RAAF Base Williamtown|RAAF Station Williamtown]], New South Wales.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 308 Pollard was appointed Director of Personnel Administration at Army Headquarters in January 1949. One of his tasks was to prepare the ground for the reintroduction of compulsory national service; the [[National Service Act 1951|new scheme]] was enacted in 1951 and remained in force until 1959.{{cite web|url=http://www.naa.gov.au/collection/fact-sheets/fs163.aspx|title=National Service, 1951–59|publisher=[[National Archives of Australia]]|accessdate=14 May 2015}} Pollard's lieutenant-colonelcy had been made [[Substantive rank|substantive]] in September 1946 and his colonelcy in July 1949. He attended the [[Imperial Defence College]], London, throughout 1951; he served as [[aide-de-camp]] to [[George VI|King George VI]] from April that year until August 1952, and in the same capacity for [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] until April 1954. In January 1952, Pollard succeeded Colonel [[John Wilton (general)|John Wilton]] as Director of Military Operations and Plans at Army Headquarters, and became Chairman of the Joint Planning Committee.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article69242341 |title=Australian for artillery talks |newspaper=[[The Advocate (Australia)|The Advocate]] |date=9 January 1952 |accessdate=14 May 2015 |page=4 }} That August he was one of the Australian delegates joining the [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Australia)|Minister for External Affairs]], [[Richard Casey, Baron Casey|Richard Casey]], for the inaugural meeting of the [[ANZUS]] Council in [[Honolulu]]; the US and New Zealand delegations were led, respectively, by Secretary of State [[Dean Acheson]] and Minister for External Affairs [[Clifton Webb (politician)|Clifton Webb]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18275383 |title=Pact talks in Hawaii |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=30 July 1952 |accessdate=14 May 2015 |page=2}} Pollard also took part in planning for the [[Operation Hurricane|atomic test at Montebello]], Western Australia, in October 1952.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2865601 |title=New type of weapon experts believe |newspaper=The Canberra Times |date=4 October 1952 |accessdate=14 May 2015 |page=1 }} Promoted to temporary [[brigadier]] in March 1953, Pollard acted as Australian military advisor to Prime Minister [[Robert Menzies]] at the [[Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference]] in London that June.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27165519 |title=PM will speak on world situation |newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |date=4 June 1953 |accessdate=18 May 2015 |page=2 }} From July to November he served as commander of the Australian Army Component of the [[British Commonwealth Forces Korea]]; the role was responsible for managing the turnover of Australian troops in the theatre and the upkeep of their personal records.O'Neill, ''Combat Operations'', p. 238 Pollard was later appointed Deputy Adjutant General at Army Headquarters, and his rank of brigadier became substantive in December 1953. In September 1954, Pollard was promoted to temporary [[Major General (Australia)|major general]] and appointed Quartermaster General and Third Military Member of the Military Board. At fifty-two, he was the youngest member of the Board.Horner, ''Strategic Command'', p. 200 His promotion to major general was made substantive in December 1954. Inspecting conditions for Australian troops deployed to [[Malayan Emergency|Malaya]] in December 1955, Pollard was quoted as saying that there were "one or two" serious complaints but that he was "amazed how few there were, considering that the average soldier complains considerably all the time".{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71784516 |title=Check-up on Malaya force |newspaper=The Argus |date=6 December 1955 |accessdate=14 May 2015 |page=22 }}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article91214589 |title=Malaya force has complaints |newspaper=The Canberra Times|date=23 December 1955 |accessdate=14 May 2015 |page=1 }} In August 1957, he was promoted [[lieutenant general]] and succeeded [[Eric Woodward]] as General Officer Commanding [[2nd Military District (Australia)|Eastern Command]], upon Woodward's appointment as [[Governor of New South Wales]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article105903019 |title=General Pollard new Army chief of staff |newspaper=The Canberra Times|date=18 February 1960 |accessdate=14 May 2015 |page=2 }}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article91594846 |title=NSW Governor farewelled |newspaper=The Canberra Times |date=1 August 1957 |accessdate=16 May 2015 |page=1 }} Headquartered in Sydney, Eastern Command covered the state of [[New South Wales]] and was the superior headquarters for the [[2nd Division (Australia)|2nd Division]] (CMF).Palazzo, ''The Australian Army'', pp. 224, 238 Pollard was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in the [[Queen's Birthday Honours]] promulgated on 9 June 1955,{{LondonGazette |issue=40498 |date=9 June 1955 |startpage=3298 |supp=yes |accessdate=10 May 2015}} and a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] in the Birthday Honours promulgated on 13 June 1959.{{LondonGazette |issue=41728 |date=13 June 1959 |startpage=3735 |supp=yes |accessdate=10 May 2015}} ===Chief of the General Staff=== On 1 July 1960, Pollard succeeded Lieutenant General [[Ragnar Garrett|Sir Ragnar Garrett]] as [[Chief of Army (Australia)|Chief of the General Staff]] (CGS), and was raised to [[Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in the Queen's Birthday Honours promulgated on 2 June 1961.Horner ''Strategic Command'', pp. 194–195{{LondonGazette |issue=42371 |date=2 June 1961 |startpage=4180 |supp=yes |accessdate=10 May 2015}} Although favoured by Garrett, Pollard's succession had not been a foregone conclusion. The [[Department of the Army (Australia)|Minister for the Army]], [[John Cramer (Australian politician)|John Cramer]], attempted to appoint Major General [[Ivan Dougherty]], a retired CMF officer, but the proposal was defeated in [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] on the advice of the [[Minister for Defence (Australia)|Minister for Defence]], [[Athol Townley]], who feared the antagonism it was likely to engender among the senior ranks of the Regular Army.Grey, ''The Australian Army'', pp. 199–200 As CGS, Pollard oversaw a major restructure of the Army. Following the lead of the US military, in 1960 the Australian Army replaced its "triangular" divisional structure of three infantry battalions under brigade headquarters, with a "[[Pentropic organisation|pentropic]]" organisation consisting of five larger battalions without a brigade layer between division and battalion headquarters.Grey, ''The Australian Army'', pp. 204–207 The reorganisation had been sponsored by Garrett and agreed to by Townley in December 1959.McNeill, ''To Long Tan'', p. 13 According to historian Chris Clark, Pollard was "personally ambivalent" about the change, which was intended to rationalise resources and strengthen the battalions for overseas deployments but also resulted in the disbandment of the citizens' brigades and many other militia units. The US in any case abandoned the pentropic system in June 1961, and the Australian Army ultimately returned to the triangular formation following a review commissioned by Pollard's successor as CGS, Lieutenant General Wilton, in October 1964.Grey, ''The Australian Army'', pp. 209Dennis et al, ''Oxford Companion to Australian Military History'', pp. 419–420 Another of Pollard's focus areas as CGS was the academic qualifications of Army officers. Concerned that Duntroon graduates would begin to fall behind their tertiary-educated peers in the community, he worked to make the college a degree-granting institution, though this did not come to fruition until 1968.Moore, ''Duntroon'', pp. 269–275 In December 1961, Pollard told the Secretary of the Defence Committee that he considered the Army's strength inadequate to support the government's policy of "forward defence", which involved meeting Communist aggression in South East Asia, well away from the Australian mainland. The CMF, he contended, was not properly equipped to provide relief for regular forces deployed overseas, and conscription "would appear to be politically and economically out of the question".Horner, ''Strategic Command'', pp. 198, 396 Nevertheless, the government [[National Service Act 1964|reintroduced conscription in 1964]].McNeill, ''To Long Tan'', p. 25 As the threat of [[South Vietnam]] falling to a Communist takeover became more apparent, the Army began in 1962 to exercise specifically to combat [[counter-insurgency]] operations, a type of warfare Pollard characterised as "frustrating groping at an elusive enemy"; he added that "no purely military solution to a Communist insurgency situation is possible".McNeill, ''To Long Tan'', p. 12 In May that year, the Federal government agreed to South Vietnam's request for military instructors; Pollard was responsible for laying down guidelines for the thirty advisors deployed in August as part of the [[Australian Army Training Team Vietnam]], led by his friend Colonel [[Ted Serong]].McNeill, ''To Long Tan'', pp. 38–39Horner, ''Strategic Command'', p. 215 ==Retirement== Upon reaching the mandatory retirement age of sixty, Pollard left the military on 20 January 1963, having recommended Wilton as his successor. He became a [[Pastoral farming|grazier]] on a farm at [[Wesburn, Victoria|Wesburn]], Victoria. In July 1965, he was made [[Honorary Colonel]] (later [[Colonel Commandant]]) of the [[Royal Australian Regiment]], in which capacity he visited Australian troops in South Vietnam. He served as Australian Secretary to [[Queen Elizabeth II]] for the Royal Visit in 1970, and was appointed a [[Knight Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] in recognition of his services; the honour was promulgated on 29 May 1970, backdated to 3 May.{{LondonGazette |issue=45110 |date=29 May 1970 |startpage=6039|endpage=6040 |accessdate=10 May 2015}} In 1974, he moved to a new property, which he christened ''Duntroon'', at [[Wyrallah, New South Wales|Wyrallah]], New South Wales. Pollard died suddenly at his Wyrallah home on 9 March 1978. He was survived by his wife and two sons, and cremated.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article110887104 |title=In brief: General dies |newspaper=The Canberra Times |date=11 March 1978
